alert.note: Alert for Southern Seward Peninsula Coast (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued May 12 at 2:10PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks
info.description: ...Minor Ice Shoves Strong winds and Heavy Rain Possible This Weekend and Next Week... A strong front moving east out of the Bering Sea will stall over the area this weekend and into early next week. This front is expected to bring strong southerly winds and the potential for minor ice shoves along the Northern Coast of Norton Sound over the weekend. In addition, heavy rain is expected especially along the south facing slopes of the Seward Peninsula through the weekend and into early next week. The heavy rain combined with an above normal snowpack over higher elevations, will cause a significant increase in snowmelt. Runoff into rivers along the south facing slopes of the Seward Peninsula over the weekend and early next week will cause water levels to rise and the potential to start the breakup process on many rivers. Local ice jam may form and result in elevated water levels. The increased runoff may also cause smaller streams and creeks to rise to bankfull levels or overbank in low lying areas. People along rivers and streams along the West Coast should prepare for the possibility of high water levels this week and next week due to potential ice breakup and snowmelt runoff. People along the Northern Coast of the Seward Peninsula should be prepared for minor ice shoves this weekend.
